translation.eng: Now, I will talk about feasts and potlatches.
People never had a potlatch alone by themselves.
They would call and gather their relatives and say, “we would like to do it (hold a potlatch).”
Among them there would be the advisor.
They would ask him when it should be.
They think about how long it would take to gather various things to give away.
Now, when you give a potlatch, all the relatives would chip in.
They gather various things that they will give out.

transcript.default: ʔan ʔanackʷakʔaaɬ huuʔak n̓iƛy̓ak ḥay̓um, č̓apac, p̓ačiƛy̓ak.

transcription.default: ʔan ʔanackʷakʔaaɬ huuʔak n̓iƛy̓ak ḥay̓um č̓apac p̓ačiƛy̓ak

translation.eng: A long time ago the only thing they had to give away were oars, bailers, and canoes.

transcript.default: hišumyiɬḥʔaƛ t̓apatšiƛ qʷiyucukʔitq, ʔuniccukukʔitqʔaɬ hišumy̓uup hihiqtup.

transcription.default: hišumyiɬḥʔaƛ t̓apatšiƛ qʷiyucukʔitq ʔuniccukukʔitqʔaɬ hišumy̓uup hihiqtup

translation.eng: As they gather gifts, they think about when they should have the potlatch and how long it would take to gather everything together.

transcript.default: n̓aacsaatʔaaɬ ʔaḥ t̓ut̓učkiɬ k̓acḥaq ƛ̓iƛ̓ick̓uk, qʷiquusii.

transcription.default: n̓aacsaatʔaaɬ ʔaḥ t̓ut̓učkiɬ k̓acḥaq ƛ̓iƛ̓ick̓uk qʷiquusii

translation.eng: You would see piles of blankets, flour or whatever.

transcript.default: ʔan ḥaaʔuuyiʔaaɬckʷatʔaaɬʔaɬ k̓acḥaq, hapumy̓amumʔak saštup ʔayiičiʔaƛukquu.

transcription.default: ʔan ḥaaʔuuyiʔaaɬckʷatʔaaɬʔaɬ k̓acḥaq hapumy̓amumʔak saštup ʔayiičiʔaƛukquu

translation.eng: They could get animal furs exchanged for blankets when you get lots.
You would know when you get enough.
Sometimes he would give a potlatch just for the band members.
Sometimes you would invite other tribes.
